School of Materials and Metallurgy Inner Mongolia University of Science and Technology Baotou Inner Mongolia 014000 China CePO4 was prepared using the co-precipitation method. Recognizing the bifunctional nature of hetero-polyacid (salt), with both acidic and redox properties, it was modified by using phosphotungstic acid (HPW), and the HPW/CePO4 catalysts were synthesized using the impregnation technique. Various advanced techniques were employed to investigate aspects such as catalytic activity, microstructure, surface properties, and reaction mechanisms. These methods included NH3-SCR, XRD, XPS, SEM, BET, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and In-situ DRIFTs. Experimental findings indicated that the HPW-modified CePO4 catalysts exhibited enhanced SCR activity. Among them, the reaction activity window for NO x conversion of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst was found to be 300∼400 °C, which represented the best activity temperature window. Following the incorporation of HPW, the HPW/CePO4 catalysts demonstrated an increased presence of Brønsted acidic sites, which concurrently led to a significant reduction in SO2 adsorption. The W: Ce 0.05 catalyst possessed the highest ratios of Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) and Ce4+/(Ce3++Ce4+). These ratios effectively regulated the sequestration and release of reactive oxygen species, thereby enhancing the activation of NH3. Consequently, this promoted the catalyst's low-temperature NH3-SCR reactivity. Lastly, the reaction process was examined using in-situ DRIFTs. The study revealed the generation of -NH2 intermediates at the Lewis acid sites of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. These intermediates subsequently underwent reactions with gaseous NO via the Eley-Rideal mechanism. This approach not only amplified the low-temperature catalytic efficacy of the catalysts but also bolstered their resilience to SO2, thereby fostering the long-term stability of the NH3-SCR reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CePo4 Phosphotungstic acid NH3-Scr In-situ DRIFTs Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As socioeconomic development progresses and human production activities expand, the increased consumption of coal, diesel, and gasoline results in elevated NO x emissions. These emissions are implicated in various environmental concerns, such as ozone layer depletion, acid rain, photochemical smog, the greenhouse effect, and haze [1–3]. These emissions not only hinder sustainable socioeconomic development but also pose a significant health threat to the populace. NO x can cause irreparable damage to the human respiratory system and impede the healthy development of children's lungs [4–6]. To mitigate NO x emissions, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is the predominant approach employed for flue gas denitrification. Among the well-recognized SCR catalysts are those based on vanadium. However, they have notable disadvantages, including a requirement for high operating temperatures, limited activity at low temperatures, biotoxicity, and potential hazards to both environmental and human health [7,8]. Consequently, the advancement of novel and efficient NH3-SCR catalysts has emerged as a central focus in research. Recently, CePO4 catalysts have garnered attention due to their enhanced resistance to water and sulfur. Zeng et al. [9] employed the co-precipitation method to fabricate a series of CePO4, FePO4, and Fe x Ce1- x catalysts to investigate their catalytic performance in the NH3-SCR process. At 330 °C, the NO x conversion of both the CePO4 and Fe0.3Ce0.7 catalysts remained unaffected by the presence of H2O and SO2. Furthermore, both the CePO4 and the Fe x Ce1- x catalysts adhered to the E-R reaction mechanism during transient reactions. Liu et al. [10] employed the hydrothermal impregnation technique to synthesize MO x (M = Cu, Mn, Co) on CePO4 supports. The characterization results indicated that the carrier, namely CePO4, served as an acidic site, resulting in the generation of highly active NH4 + ions. These ions then interacted synergistically with MnO x , enhancing the NH3-SCR catalytic activity. Furthermore, the MO x /CePO4 catalyst demonstrated outstanding resistance to water. Zhao et al. [11] synthesized CePO4 catalysts with various crystalline phases. They discovered that the catalysts with a pure hexagonal phase of CePO4 showcased a greater abundance of Brønsted acidic sites, superior activity stability, and enhanced resistance to both water and sulfur compared to those with a pure monoclinic phase. Modification with hetero-polyacid enhances the acidic sites of the catalysts and the efficiency of NO x catalysis. Wu et al. [12] utilized H3PW12O40 (HPW) to modify Fe2O3 catalysts via the impregnation method. They examined the influence of HPW modification on the NH3-SCR catalytic performance of the catalysts. Following modification with HPW, there was a marked increase in the quantity of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the surface of the catalysts. This led to greater oxygen adsorption, enhancing NH3 adsorption. Consequently, the catalysts demonstrated outstanding resistance to SO2 and selectivity for N2. The HPW/Fe2O3–350–0.5 catalyst attained near-total NO x conversion within the temperature range of 240 to 460 °C. In-situ DRIFTs findings indicated that the NH3-SCR reaction on these catalysts predominantly followed the Eley-Rideal mechanism. Tang et al. [13] reported a mechanistic study on Mn-Ce-Co catalysts modified with HPW. The HPW-Mn-Ce-Co catalysts achieved a NO x conversion rate of up to 100 % within the temperature range of 100 to 250 °C. The incorporation of HPW enhanced the surface acidity of the catalysts and increased oxygen vacancies, leading to heightened redox capacity. Findings from in-situ DRIFTs suggested that the HPW-Mn-Ce-Co catalysts largely followed the Eley-Rideal mechanism. Weng et al. [14] modified a CeO2 catalyst using HPW. HPW can absorb NO2, inhibiting its further oxidation to nitrate. This process enriches the catalyst's surface with Brønsted acidic sites, significantly enhancing its catalytic performance for SCR. HPW served as a protective layer for CeO2, imparting the catalyst with robust SO2 resistance. In this study, a CePO4 catalyst was fabricated using the co-precipitation technique to improve its resistance to sulfur and water, as well as boost its NO x catalytic efficiency. Subsequently, this catalyst was modified using HPW acidification to produce HPW/CePO4 catalysts. A series of experiments were conducted to explore the enhancement mechanism of the HPW-modified catalysts. Catalytic performance tests revealed that HPW modification effectively increased the acidic sites and oxygen vacancies on the CePO4 catalyst, thereby boosting its NH3-SCR activity. Using in-situ DRIFTs, the key reactive oxygen and nitrate species were identified on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. Based on these findings, a plausible reaction mechanism for the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst in the NH3-SCR process was postulated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ce (NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water and subjected to stirring on a magnetic hotplate stirrer for 30 min, using the co-precipitation technique. A stoichiometric solution of phosphoric acid, maintaining a n Ce: n P ratio of 1, was subsequently introduced. The pH of the mixture was brought to 5 by the addition of ammonia. After this adjustment, the solution was subjected to intense stirring for an additional 2 h and subsequently permitted to age at ambient temperature for 24 h. Following the aging process, the mixture was isolated and subjected to four washes. The resultant solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C and subsequently calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for a duration of 4 h, producing the CePO4 catalyst. HPW was dissolved in a suitable volume of deionized water at stoichiometric ratios (n W: n Ce of 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, and 0.2) using the impregnation technique. CePO4 was subsequently added to this solution, and the mixture was subjected to stirring on a magnetic hotplate stirrer for 2 h, after which it was allowed to stand for 24 h. The catalysts were then dried in an oven at 105 °C for a duration of 12 h, followed by calcination in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 5 h, yielding the HPW/CePO4 catalysts. The products thus obtained were designated as W: Ce (X), with X representing 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, or 0.2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization An X-ray diffraction analyzer (XRD) was employed to characterize the lattice structure of the catalyst's physical phase. The instrument employed was an Axios type from Panalytical, Netherlands. The analyzer operated with a stepwise scanning method, a voltage and current of 40 kV and 40 mA were employed, respectively, along with a scanning speed of 3°/min and a 2θ scanning range from 10° to 80° The morphology of the catalyst was investigated using a Sigma-500 scanning electron microscope (SEM) manufactured by Zeiss, Germany. Additionally, an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) was integrated with the SEM, employing characteristic X-ray wavelengths for both quantitative and qualitative analysis of the catalyst's elemental composition. Observations were conducted at magnifications ranging from 10 to 1,000kx. The catalyst's microscopic morphology and surface elemental composition were examined using a JEM-2100 (HR) transmission electron microscope (TEM) from Nihon Electronics Corporation. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the catalyst were evaluated using a 3S-2000PS1 analyzer provided by Best Instruments Inc. The specific surface area of the catalyst was ascertained utilizing the BET equation, whereas its pore size and volume were determined based on the BJH method. The catalyst's redox properties were assessed using a PCA-1200 chemisorbentimeter from Beijing Piande Electronics Corporation, designed for H2-programmed temperature chemisorption. H2 consumption signals were recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The strength and quantity of the catalyst surface acidic sites were analyzed using a PCA-1200 chemisorption instrument from Beijing Piande Company, designed for NH3-programmed temperature desorption. The effluent gas was detected using a Hiden QIC-200 mass spectrometer, and the NH3 desorption curve was captured via the TCD signal. An ESCALAB250ZI high-performance imaging X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) from Thermo Fisher, USA, was employed to analyze the valence and content of elements present on the catalyst surface. The binding energy of C 1 s, recorded at 284.8 eV, was used as the calibration reference for each element. An in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectrometer recorded real-time alterations in the surface species of the catalyst, contributing to insights into the mechanism of its catalytic reaction. The spectrometer employed was a VERTEX70 from Bruker, Germany, equipped with a PIKE DRIFT catalyst cell and a high-precision MCT detector that was cooled with liquid nitrogen. 2.3 Catalytic performance test In this study, the denitrification activity of the catalyst was assessed using an apparatus designed for NH3-SCR activity testing. This apparatus encompasses a gas distribution system, a temperature control system, and an exhaust gas analysis system. The simulated flue gas mixture consisted of 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, and 6 vol.% O2, with the remainder being N2. The total flow rate was 300 mL/min, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 36,000 h−1. Experiment parameters were set via the thermostat. Subsequently, 0.2 g of the catalyst sample was measured and placed in a quartz glass tube, anchored at the bottom with quartz wool. Beginning at 100 °C and escalating at a rate of 10 °C/min, the NO concentration of the gas at the reactor's inlet and outlet was documented. Temperature observation points were established every 50 °C, continuing up to 500 °C. In the SCR activity test, the NO x conversion and N2 selectivity of the catalyst were determined using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively: (1) N O x conversion % = ( [ N O x ] in − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in ) × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity % = ( 1 − [ N O 2 ] out + 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ N O x ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N O x ] out − [ N H 3 ] out ) × 100 % In the equation presented earlier, the terms [NO2]out, [N2O]out, and [NH3]out respectively signify the concentrations of NO2, N2O, and NH3 at the reactor's exit, quantified in ppm. In a parallel context, [NH3]in designates the concentration of NH3 at the reactor's entry, also expressed in ppm. It should be noted that the total [NO x ] is the summation of [NO] and [NO2]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance As depicted in Fig. 1 (a) and (b), the graphs display the NH3-SCR activity test data and N2 selectivity test results for the CePO4 catalyst and HPW/CePO4 catalysts with various W/Ce ratios for HPW treatment, respectively. As evident from Fig. 1(a), the NO x conversion of the CePO4 catalyst exhibited the poorest performance in the temperature range of 200∼500 °C, with the SCR activity being the best when the temperature reached 350 °C, and the NO x conversion was only 80.4 %. After modification with HPW, the CePO4 catalysts exhibited a significant enhancement in their catalytic activity. The activity window of the catalysts broadened, exhibiting improved catalytic performance within the temperature range of 250∼500 °C. The W: Ce 0.05 catalyst, in particular, demonstrated the widest activity temperature window and superior low-temperature activity, achieving a NO x conversion rate of 94.1 % within the temperature range of 300∼400 °C. At 350 °C, the NO x conversion rates were 84.2 % for W: Ce 0.01, 86.7 % for W: Ce 0.1, and 83.2 % for W: Ce 0.15. The W: Ce 0.2 catalyst showed suboptimal NH3-SCR activity. These results indicate that HPW modification enhanced the catalytic activity and expanded the operational temperature range. However, excessive HPW reduced high-temperature activity. Fig. 1(b) revealed that the HPW-treated catalysts demonstrated superior performance compared to the CePO4 catalysts. This indicates that HPW modification not only expanded the temperature range for SCR catalytic activity but also markedly enhanced N2 selectivity, a crucial factor for reducing the environmental impact of greenhouse gasses. In addition to the above studies, the activity stability and water and sulfur poisoning resistance of W: Ce 0.05 catalyst were further investigated, as depicted in Fig. 1(c) and (d), respectively. From Fig. 1(c), it was evident that the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst sustained a catalytic activity of approximately 94.1 % for 50 h at 300 °C. Moreover, during four-cycle tests with temperatures ranging from 210 °C to 340 °C, its NO x conversion remained consistent, underscoring the catalyst's robust activity stability. In Fig. 1(d), it was observed that introducing 5 vol% H2O led to a slight reduction in NO x conversion efficiency, dropping from an initial 85.4 % to approximately 82.6 % at 250 °C. Notably, once water exposure ceased, its performance promptly returned to baseline within an hour. Furthermore, when exposed to 100 ppm SO2, NO x conversion modestly declined to around 82.1 %. Remarkably, after discontinuing SO2 exposure, efficiency swiftly rebounded, reaching nearly 85.1 % within an hour. In a combined environment of 5 vol% H2O and 100 ppm SO2, the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst experienced a gradual dip in its NO x conversion but consistently maintained a level above 80.6 %. These results underscore the remarkable robustness and resilience of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst, even when facing potentially detrimental factors such as H2O and SO2. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Structural characteristics XRD Fig. 2 displays the XRD spectra of both CePO4 and HPW/CePO4 catalysts. This aimed to explore the alterations in the crystalline phases of the catalysts’ surface materials due to HPW modification. All samples exhibited distinct characteristic peaks at 2θ values of 14.5°, 20.0°, 25.2°, 29.2°, 31.4°, 37.8°, 42.1°, 46.7°, and 48.5°, corresponding to the (100), (101), (110), (200), (102), (112), (211), (301), and (212) crystal planes, respectively. The CePO4 matched the standard spectrum for the hexagonal crystal system (PDF 34–1380) [15]. No diffraction peaks attributable to HPW were evident in the HPW/CePO4 catalysts, suggesting a high degree of HPW dispersion on the catalysts’ surface [16]. Using Scherrer's formula, the average cell parameters and grain sizes of the (100) crystalline surfaces for the various samples were calculated, as detailed in Table 1 . The lattice parameter for CePO4 was found to be 7.4 Å, while the lattice parameters of HPW/CePO4 catalysts with different W/Ce ratios were smaller than those of the CePO4 catalyst. The grain size for CePO4 was measured at 11.2 nm, in contrast to 9.8 nm for W: Ce 0.01, 10.7 nm for W: Ce 0.05, 10.3 nm for W: Ce 0.1, 9.3 nm for W: Ce 0.15, and 10.6 nm for W: Ce 0.2 catalysts. Compared to the pristine CePO4 catalyst, the HPW/CePO4 composites demonstrated notably finer grain structures. This enhanced microstructural refinement, a direct consequence of incorporating HPW, corroborated previous studies [17] highlighting its role in curbing undue grain enlargement and inducing crystallographic alterations in the catalysts’ matrix. 3.2.2 Surface morphology analysis Fig. 3 displayed the microzone SEM patterns of the CePO4 and W: Ce 0.05 catalysts. In Fig. 3(a), the CePO4 catalyst was shown to possess a large, spherical granular structure with an uneven surface morphology, resembling a honeycomb pattern. Fig. 3(b) showcased the catalyst after HPW loading. While it still consisted of agglomerated large spheres, there was evident shedding from these larger particles, resulting in the formation of finer particles. Notable acid erosion traces were present on the surface. The introduction of HPW led to a looser, more porous structure [18], giving the surface a fluffy appearance and revealing more surface defects. These defects offered ample reaction sites for catalytic experiments, potentially enhancing the catalyst's denitrification efficiency. Fig. 4 displayed the EDS-Mapping pattern of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst, illustrating the distribution of elements on its surface. The elements Ce, P, and O, constituting the catalyst, were present in high concentrations and were uniformly distributed throughout. Similarly, the element W exhibited a uniform distribution, suggesting that HPW was well-dispersed across the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst's surface [19]. This observation aligned with the XRD findings. The introduction of HPW altered the surface properties of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its activity. 3.2.3 Microscopic morphology analysis Fig. 5 displays the TEM images (a-d) and HRTEM images (e-h) of the catalysts. In Fig. 5(a), CePO4 was shown to possess a nanorod-like structure, consistent with observations from the SEM morphology. From Fig. 5(b-d), the W: Ce 0.05, W: Ce 0.1, and W: Ce 0.2 catalysts maintained their nanorod-like structures. However, these structures appeared more fibrous and extended, potentially accounting for the heightened catalytic activity observed in the HPW-modified catalysts [20]. From Fig. 5(e–h), the lattice fringe spacings for the CePO4, W: Ce 0.05, W: Ce 0.1, and W: Ce 0.2 catalysts were measured as 0.6172 nm, 0.6135 nm, 0.6126 nm, and 0.6153 nm, respectively. These values correspond to the hexagonal crystalline system of the cerium (100) phosphate crystal planes, aligning with the XRD data (PDF 34–1380). Additionally, the lattice spacings of the W: Ce 0.05, W: Ce 0.1, and W: Ce 0.2 catalysts were smaller than that of the CePO4 catalyst. This observation was likely due to the effects of the HPW treatment, including thermal impacts, leading to alterations in the crystal structures and consequently, a reduction in lattice spacing. Post-HPW treatment, the respective peak positions in the XRD patterns shifted to higher angles, mirroring the lattice spacing decrease. This alignment was further corroborated by experimental data. 3.2.4 Specific surface area and pore size analysis Fig. 6 presents the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of the CePO4 and HPW/CePO4 catalysts, accompanied by their respective BJH pore distribution curves. As classified by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), all six catalysts displayed characteristic type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops [21]. From Fig. 6(a), it was evident that the CePO4 catalyst exhibited increased nitrogen adsorption at relative pressures above 0.9, suggesting the existence of mesoporous and macroporous structures on its surface. Figs. 6(b–f) demonstrated that the HPW-treated catalysts (W: Ce 0.01, W: Ce 0.05, W: Ce 0.1, W: Ce 0.15, and W: Ce 0.2) all exhibited pronounced hysteresis and heightened volumetric nitrogen adsorption, akin to that observed in the CePO4 catalyst. This suggests that the meso‑ and macroporous structures remained intact even after HPW modification [22]. The inset of Fig. 6 presented the BJH pore size distribution curve, indicating that the CePO4 catalyst predominantly featured macropores. In contrast, the HPW/CePO4 catalysts exhibited a significant increase in mesopores quantities. Table 2 presents the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size metrics of CePO4 and its variants modified with HPW. Notably, the unadulterated CePO4 catalyst stood out with a remarkable specific surface area of 91.5 m2/g. In contrast, the catalyst variants W: Ce 0.01 through W: Ce 0.2 consistently showed a decrease in their specific surface areas. Furthermore, the dataset highlighted the pore volume and average pore size of the pristine CePO4 catalyst, measured at 0.29 mL/g and 13.8 nm, respectively. Intriguingly, after HPW incorporation, a consistent decline in both pore volume and average pore size was discernible across all modified catalysts’ variants. Generally, enhancements in both specific surface area and pore volume are positively correlated with catalytic efficacy [23]. However, despite demonstrating superior catalytic activity, the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst possessed a specific surface area that was smaller than that of the unmodified CePO4 catalyst. This could be potentially explained by HPW's characteristic as a “pseudo-liquid phase” [24,25]. Upon gas absorption, heteropolymeric compounds in HPW transformed into a structure reminiscent of a concentrated solution. Consequently, the catalytic reaction might occur not only on the surface but also within the interior of the acid. The data indicated that the specific surface area of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst was not the critical factor influencing the NH3-SCR catalytic process. 3.3 H2-TPR results Fig. 7 (a) and (b) show the redox characteristics and H2 consumption of the CePO4 catalyst and HPW/CePO4 catalysts with different W/Ce ratios, respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 7(a), the CePO4 catalyst displayed almost no reduction peak, indicating its high structural stability. This also implied that Ce3+ ions were resistant to reduction [26]. Following the modifications with HPW, there were notable alterations in the reduction behavior of the CePO4 catalysts. From the figure, it was observed that for all HPW-treated catalysts, a reduction peak emerges between 500 and 600 °C. Given that HPW undergoes decomposition to form WO3 at 572 °C, this observed reduction peak was attributed to the reduction of W6+ to W4+ [12]. Fig. 7(b) delineated the redox prowess of the four distinct catalysts, as evidenced by the variations in their H2 consumption rates. The sequence of their redox capabilities was delineated as follows: W: Ce 0.05 outperformed W: Ce 0.15, which in turn surpassed W: Ce 0.01, followed by W: Ce 0.2, with W: Ce 0.1 exhibiting the least activity. The improved redox capacity resulted in a marked enhancement of the NH3-SCR reaction, leading to a substantial increase in NO x conversion as well as an optimized activity temperature range. Furthermore, after the incorporation of HPW, all catalysts exhibited superior SCR activity compared to that exhibited by the CePO4 catalyst. This indicated that the SCR activity was not solely reliant on its redox properties, but was also closely associated with both the abundance and strength of its acidity. 3.4 NH3-TPD results Fig. 8 (a) and (b) illustrate the surface acidity distribution and NH3 desorption of the CePO4 catalyst and HPW/CePO4 catalysts with different W/Ce ratios, respectively. Desorption occurring within the temperature range of 25 to 200 °C is typically categorized as low-temperature desorption and is attributed to the presence of Brønsted weak acid centers [27]. Meanwhile, desorption detected between 200 and 450 °C is categorized as medium-temperature desorption and is associated with both medium Brønsted and Lewis acid centers [28]. Desorption taking place at temperatures above 450 °C is typically classified as high-temperature desorption and is attributed to the presence of Lewis strong acid centers [29]. As can be seen from Fig. 8(a), the CePO4 catalyst demonstrated a distinct NH3 desorption peak in the temperature range of 100 to 300 °C. This phenomenon was ascribed to the desorption of NH3 from the P-site on the surface of the CePO4 catalyst [30]. Following the incorporation of HPW, a pronounced initial NH3 desorption peak was observed for the HPW/CePO4 catalysts, centered approximately at 190 °C. These desorption phenomena could be ascribed to the liberation of NH3 from the Brønsted weak acidic centers. Upon the incorporation of HPW, the W6+ species within HPW engaged in a dynamic electronic interplay with the Ce ions inherent to CePO4. This intricate interaction resulted in the formation of novel acidic sites. Notably, HPW acted as a reservoir of Brønsted acidic moieties, whereas the Ce entities in CePO4, through their liaison with W6+, morphed into Lewis acidic epicenters. This harmonious synergy amplified the catalysts’ intrinsic acidity, giving rise to discernible desorption peaks proximate to 350 °C. Therefore, the desorption peaks that appeared at around 350 °C could be attributed to the synergistic interaction of moderate-intensity Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites. As can be seen from Fig. 8(b), the CePO4 catalyst only had weak acids. Upon the inclusion of HPW, there was a notable emergence of medium acid sites across the catalysts. The integration of HPW into the CePO4 framework not only augmented its inherent weak acid potential but also introduced a pronounced medium acid characteristic to the composite. Based on the data provided, introducing an optimal amount of HPW to the CePO4 catalyst enhanced its medium-strong acidic sites. Enhanced medium-strong acidic sites played a crucial role in boosting the denitrification efficiency of selective catalytic reduction SCR catalysts. 3.5 Surface element valence analysis Fig. 9 depicts the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) profiles for the Ce 3d, O 1 s, P 2p, and W 4f elements in HPW/CePO4 catalysts with varying W/Ce ratios. As illustrated in Fig. 9(a), the split-peak fitting for the Ce 3d orbitals revealed peaks at V1 (881.7 eV), V2 (882.6 eV), V3 (886.8 eV), V4 (900.1 eV), V5 (901.3 eV), V6 (901.7 eV), V7 (907.7 eV), and V8 (914.7 eV), which are characteristic of Ce4+. The peaks at U1 (885.4 eV) and U2 (904.3 eV) were associated with the characteristic peaks of Ce3+ [9]. The proportion of Ce4+ was determined by calculating the peak area, and the findings are presented in Table 3 . Upon the incorporation of HPW into the CePO4 catalyst matrix, electronic interplay emerged between the introduced W6+ species from HPW and the cerium ions. This synergistic interaction culminated in an accentuated presence of surface Ce4+. Intriguingly, when the W/Ce molar ratio attained 0.05, the HPW/CePO4 catalyst manifested an apex in its Ce4+ content, reaching an impressive 17.9 %. The concurrent existence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ on the catalysts’ surface facilitated the dynamic capture and liberation of reactive oxygen species. This molecular ballet significantly augmented the catalysts’ efficacy in the NH3-SCR reactions. Fig. 9(b) illustrates the analysis of surface oxygen on the catalyst, as conducted by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The O 1 s spectrum could be decomposed into three distinct peaks: one spanning from 530.5 to 530.9 eV, associated with lattice oxygen (Oβ) in metal oxides; a second peak from 531.1 to 531.6 eV, attributed to surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oα); and a third peak in the range of 532.6 to 532.9 eV, corresponding to hydroxyl oxygen in water molecules (Oγ) [31]. The relative content of Oα was determined by calculating the peak area, and the findings are presented in Table 3. The amount of chemisorbed oxygen on the HPW/CePO4 catalysts’ surface increased after HPW was added. At a W/Ce ratio of 0.05, the proportion of Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) reached its peak at 49.9 %. A high Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) ratio promoted NO oxidation, contributing to the “fast SCR reaction” [32] and improving the catalysts’ denitrification efficiency. As shown in Fig. 9(c), the P 2p spectrum of the catalyst featured two prominent peaks: one at about 133.8 eV, attributed to P2O5, and another at approximately 132.9 eV, linked to PO3 − [33]. Using the calculated peak areas, the relative contents of PO3 − and P2O5 were determined. As delineated in Table 3, upon employing the HPW/CePO4 catalysts with a W/Ce molar ratio of 0.05, the fraction of P2O5 relative to the combined presence of P2O5 and PO3 − reached an apex of 69.9 %. This indicated that the inclusion of HPW encouraged the development of P2O5 on the catalysts’ surface, which in turn boosted the catalysts’ NH3-SCR denitrification efficiency [34]. Fig. 9(d) displayed the XPS spectrum of W 4f, revealing two peaks with characteristic binding energies at 35.9 and 37.8 eV, corresponding to W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2, respectively [35]. The binding energy difference of 1.9 eV between these peaks suggested that the W species on the catalysts’ surface predominantly existed as W6+. Interactions between W6+ and Ce3+ played a role in enhancing the catalytic performance of the catalysts [36]. 3.6 In-situ DRIFTs studies 3.6.1 Adsorption of NH3/NO+O2 on the catalyst surface Fig. 10 (a) presents the NH3 adsorption spectra of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst over various time intervals. Upon introducing NH3, prominent peaks emerged at 1303, 1347, 1360, 3519, 3529, and 3626 cm−1. Up to 50 min after introducing NH3, the intensity of these peaks did not diminish or vanish, and no new peaks emerged. The peaks at 1303 and 1347 cm−1 were attributed to the chemisorption of NH3 on Lewis acid sites through co-adsorption [37]. The peak at 1360 cm−1 was ascribed to the asymmetric bending vibration of NH4 + on the Brønsted acid site [38]. Furthermore, in the 3400 to 3600 cm−1 range, two peaks appeared at 3519 and 3529 cm−1. Both peaks were ascribed to the NH stretching vibration of NH3 adsorption [39], suggesting NH3 dissociation on the catalyst surface. A hydroxyl group appeared at 3626 cm−1 [40]. In-situ DRIFTs results for NH3 adsorption revealed that NH3 molecules could stably chemisorb onto both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. In particular, NH3 interacted with Lewis acid sites, whereas Brønsted acid sites resulted in the formation of NH4 +. Both ionic NH4 + and ligand NH3 were known to play crucial roles in the NH3-SCR reaction. Additionally, the coexistence of both L and B acid sites on the catalyst was observed, a result that aligned with findings from NH3-TPD. Fig. 10(b) displays the in-situ DRIFTs spectra of NO+O2 co-adsorbed on the surface of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst over different adsorption periods. Co-adsorption of NO+O2 on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst yielded adsorption peaks at four distinct locations. Peaks at 1292 and 3529 cm−1 were attributed to monodentate nitrate species [41], while the peak at 1306 cm−1 was associated with bidentate nitrate species [42]. Additionally, the peak at 1357 cm−1 corresponded to free-state NO3 − [43]. As the adsorption time lengthened, the intensity of the peak at 1306 cm−1, representing bidentate nitrate species, increased, while the intensity of the peak at 1292 cm−1, corresponding to monodentate nitrate species, decreased. Although the peak intensity at 1292 cm−1 relatively decreased, the intensity of the monodentate nitrate remained higher than that of the bidentate nitrate. Additionally, the intensities of other peaks remained relatively stable after 5 min. Based on these observations, it was inferred that NO2 was generated during the co-adsorption of NO+O2 on the HPW-treated W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. This implied that NO was oxidized to NO2 on the surface of the catalyst, enabling either gaseous or weakly adsorbed NO2 to participate in the NH3-SCR reaction. On the catalyst surface, various nitrates could form, among which monodentate nitrate and NO2 were particularly active in the SCR reaction. The formation of these species undoubtedly boosted the NH3-SCR catalytic performance of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. 3.6.2 Thermal stability of NH3/NO+O2 on the catalyst surface Fig. 11 (a) presents the in-situ DRIFTs spectra of NH3 adsorption on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst surface over a range of temperatures. On the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst, two distinct peaks were observed. The broader peak at 3541 cm−1 was ascribed to the NH4 + species formed on the Brønsted acid site [44]. The more prominent peak at 1622 cm−1 was associated with asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of the NH bond, indicating NH3 coordination with the Lewis acid site [45]. From the figure, it was evident that the intensities of the peaks at 1622 and 3541 cm−1 decreased with increasing temperature. At 250 °C, the peak at 3541 cm−1 disappeared, while the peak at 1622 cm−1 remained visible, suggesting the continued presence of NH3 at the Lewis acid site. These results indicated that the adsorption energy of NH3 on Lewis acid sites was substantially greater than that on Brønsted acid sites. Fig. 11(b) presents the in-situ DRIFTs spectra of NO+O2 adsorption on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst surface over a range of temperatures. Adsorption peaks for NO were observed at 1566, 1620, and 3540 cm−1. The peak at 1566 cm−1 corresponded to the characteristic of monodentate nitrate [46]. The peak at 1620 cm−1 was associated with the characteristic peak of cis-N2O2 adsorbed on Ce in the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst [47]. Finally, the peak at 3540 cm−1 represented the characteristic bidentate nitrate [48]. With increasing temperature, all peaks diminished gradually. By 250 °C, the characteristic peaks of both monodentate nitrate at 1566 cm−1 and bidentate nitrate at 3540 cm−1 had disappeared. However, the characteristic peak of cis-N2O2 at 1620 cm−1 remained. These findings demonstrated that cis-N2O2 species are highly stable, remaining undisturbed below 300 °C. An increased presence of NO x species on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst surface enhanced their involvement in the NH3-SCR reaction, thus boosting the catalytic activity. 3.6.3 Transient DRIFT reaction Fig. 12 (a) presents the in-situ DRIFTs spectra for the NO+O2 reaction on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst with pre-adsorbed NH3 species. After purging with NH3 for 50 min, peaks corresponding to both the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites predominated in the spectrum. Specifically, NH4 + was associated with the Brønsted acid site, as evidenced by peaks at 1299 and 1361 cm−1 [49], while NH2 corresponded to the Lewis acid site with a peak at 1347 cm−1 [50]. After introducing NO+O2, the adsorption peaks for NH4 + at the Brønsted site of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst, found at 1299 and 1361 cm−1, disappeared. The peak corresponding to NH2 at the Lewis acid site, observed at 1347 cm−1, diminished. At the same time, several new peaks appeared, associated with the presence of monodentate nitrate (3519 cm−1), bidentate nitrite (1306 cm−1), bridged nitrate (1354 cm−1), and free-state NO3 − (3626 cm−1) [51]. This observation implied a swift reaction between pre-adsorbed NH3 and gaseous NO+O2. The appearance of nitrate species further suggests complete consumption of the pre-adsorbed NH3. Moreover, the involvement of NH2 from the Lewis acid site in the NH3-SCR reaction aligned with the E-R mechanism. Fig. 12(b) presents the in-situ DRIFTs spectra elucidating the reaction of NH3 on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst following pre-adsorption of NO+O2. Upon inspecting the spectrum for the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst that had undergone NO+O2 pre-treatment, distinctive peaks corresponding to adsorbed NO2 were evident at 1306 cm−1 and 1363 cm−1, while monodentate nitrate manifested at 1296 cm−1, and the free nitrate ion resonated at 3624 cm−1 [52,53]. After the introduction of gaseous NH3, there was a notable diminution in the intensity of the NO2 adsorption peak at 1306 cm−1. Concurrently, pronounced NH3 adsorption peaks emerged at 1354 cm−1 and 3529 cm−1. These spectral observations substantiated that the adsorbed nitrates did not engage in reactions with either gaseous NH3 or the adsorbed NH3 species. Such findings lend credence to the hypothesis that the NH3-SCR reaction on the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst is predominantly governed by the E-R mechanism. Based on the analysis provided, we examine the reaction mechanism over the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. Fig. 13 illustrates the influence of the reaction pathway. The intermediates observed during the transient reaction suggest that the NH3-SCR reaction on the catalyst surface follows the E-R mechanism. The corresponding reaction equations are as follows: (3) N H 3 ( g ) → N H 3 ( ad ) ( Lewis ) (4) N H 3 ( g ) → NH 4 ( ad ) + ( Br ø nsted ) (5) N H 3 ( ad ) + C e 4 + = O → N H 2 + C e 3 + − OH (6) C e 3 + − OH + 1 / 4 O 2 → C e 4 + = O + 1 / 2 H 2 O (7) NH 4 ( ad ) + → − N H 2 + 2 H + + e − (8) − N H 2 + NO → N H 2 NO → N 2 + H 2 O 4 Conclusion In this study, we prepared a CePO4 catalyst using the co-precipitation technique, aiming to develop a low-temperature denitrification catalyst through the addition of HPW. Activity tests revealed that the NO x conversion rate of the CePO4 catalyst was constrained between 200 °C and 500 °C. However, the reaction activity saw a notable enhancement after introducing HPW. The most effective W: Ce 0.05 catalyst achieved a 61.5 % NO x conversion at 200 °C and an impressive 94.1 % NO x conversion between 300 °C and 400 °C. Among all tested catalysts, the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst exhibited the best performance. SEM and TEM analyses revealed that the HPW/CePO4 catalysts possess a rod-like structure. XRD results further revealed that HPW is finely dispersed on the catalysts’ surface. NH3-TPD analysis showed that the integration of HPW into the CePO4 framework not only augments its inherent weak acid potential but also introduces a pronounced medium acid characteristic to the composite. Based on the findings from the H2-TPR analysis, it is evident that the reduction of W plays a pivotal role in augmenting the adsorption and subsequent activation of NH3. XPS analysis revealed that the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst displayed the highest ratios of Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) and Ce4+/(Ce3++Ce4+). The increase in Ce4+ content favored the formation of redox pairs of Ce3+/Ce4+, contributing to the catalyst's exceptional NH3-SCR catalytic activity. An in-situ DRIFTs study of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst revealed that the reduction of NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites enhances NH3-SCR activity. This reduction also promotes the formation of -NH2 intermediates, which react with gas-phase NO through the E-R mechanism. All the above-mentioned characteristics play a positive role in enhancing the anti-SO2 performance of HPW-modified CePO4 catalysts. Moreover, these insights provided a foundation for the further development of CePO4-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: CePO4 was prepared using the co-precipitation method. Recognizing the bifunctional nature of hetero-polyacid (salt), with both acidic and redox properties, it was modified by using phosphotungstic acid (HPW), and the HPW/CePO4 catalysts were synthesized using the impregnation technique. Various advanced techniques were employed to investigate aspects such as catalytic activity, microstructure, surface properties, and reaction mechanisms. These methods included NH3-SCR, XRD, XPS, SEM, BET, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and In-situ DRIFTs. Experimental findings indicated that the HPW-modified CePO4 catalysts exhibited enhanced SCR activity. Among them, the reaction activity window for NO x conversion of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst was found to be 300∼400 °C, which represented the best activity temperature window. Following the incorporation of HPW, the HPW/CePO4 catalysts demonstrated an increased presence of Brønsted acidic sites, which concurrently led to a significant reduction in SO2 adsorption. The W: Ce 0.05 catalyst possessed the highest ratios of Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) and Ce4+/(Ce3++Ce4+). These ratios effectively regulated the sequestration and release of reactive oxygen species, thereby enhancing the activation of NH3. Consequently, this promoted the catalyst's low-temperature NH3-SCR reactivity. Lastly, the reaction process was examined using in-situ DRIFTs. The study revealed the generation of -NH2 intermediates at the Lewis acid sites of the W: Ce 0.05 catalyst. These intermediates subsequently underwent reactions with gaseous NO via the Eley-Rideal mechanism. This approach not only amplified the low-temperature catalytic efficacy of the catalysts but also bolstered their resilience to SO2, thereby fostering the long-term stability of the NH3-SCR reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effects of phosphotungstic acid on CePO4 catalyst for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3
